Award.AwardTitle: Novel Optically-Activated High-Voltage and Single-Bias Wide-Bandgap High-Frequency Thyristor for Next-Generation Smart Grid

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches:

The objectives of this project are as follows: 1) To realize and optimize a high-gain, high voltage (HV) (>10 kV, >35 A), and high-temperature SiC Integrated Thyristor, which is triggered in a non-latched manner using a very low power and short-wavelength single monochromatic photonic source by hybrid integration; 2) To reduce the optical-triggering power requirement of the SiC-based Integrated Thyristor by optimization of optical-absorption efficiency, lifetime control, and localized photogeneration-recombination process; and 3) Experimental characterizations of the fabricated prototype device for performance validation.

Intellectual Merit:

The novel all-optical and single-bias (i.e. only the power bias) SiC Integrated Thyristor improves upon all core all-electrical multi-bias HV integrated thyristors including ETO/IGCT/MTO. Further, the Integrated Thyristor also provides a superior solution to the state-of-the-art SiC DMOSFET and SiC IGBT for the HV power systems in multiple aspects. The bipolar device provides numerous device and system level advantages with regard to response time and switching frequency, reliability, ease of triggering, on-state drop, current and voltage scalabilities, fabrication, thermal conductivity, electromagnetic-interference immunity, electrical isolation, and energy-conversion efficiency.

Broader Impacts:

The impact of the HV SiC Integrated Thyristor is expected to be radical with applications including direct-grid-interface solar, wind, fuel-cell inverters, energy-storage systems, FACTS, power-quality conditioners, HVDC systems, motor drives, solid-state transformers, fault-current limiters, and pulsed-power systems. The proposed project will provide doctoral education to a Ph.D. researcher. Further, multiple undergraduate (including minority) students and middle-school students will be provided research/educational opportunities. Results of the research will be integrated into an undergraduate and a graduate course at UIC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The impact of controllable high-voltage (HV) powersemiconductor devices on multiple high-power applications isexpected to be profound. With the rapid growth ofwide-bandgap materials and device technologies, the goal ofrealizing controllable HV devices is slowly materializing. HVSiC metal oxide field effect transitors (MOSFETs), SiC insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs), SiC gate turn-off thyristors (GTOs) have beendemonstrated. However, they all require plurality ofbiases for activation. 

In this project, an optical emitter turn-off (ETO) thyristor is pursued that operates with only the power bias as compared tomonolithic and hybrid electrical ETOs as well asother bipolar and insulated-gate device mentioned above. Thisis achieved via optical switching and self-triggeringmechanisms as narrated in the subsequent section. Further, thesimple optical switching scheme holds promise for seamlessoperation of series of the device for even higher voltageoperation since necessity for complex floating ground gatedrivers for electrical HV devices are eliminated. Additoinally, all-optical ETO benefits from a turn-off snubberless solution and mitigate the high di/dt and dv/dt problems associated with GTO thyristors and MOS turn-off (MTO) thyristors. Optical triggering also reduces susceptibility to electromagnetic interference for the all-optical ETO.

The all-optical ETO is completelycontrolled by two optical signals, one for the 15 kV SiC GTO thyristor and the other one for a triggering lowvoltageoptically controlled Si switch. The latter, called optically triggered power transistor (OTPT), is used in series with theanode contact of the SiC GTO thyristor in order to handle thertherecurrent switching between anode and gate path of the SiC GTOthyristor. This OTPT is triggered with a low power laser of longwavelength while the main optical SiC GTO thyristor is triggered with a laser having a short wave length. Two different variations of the OTPT have been pursued: one with a single stage (Image 1) while the other with a cascaded structure (Image 2) that reduces the optical power requirement. An experimental characterization setup (Image 3) validated the performances.

Overall, this project led to the pursuance of a novel all-optical ETO - a HV device - that if further matured can be a game changing solution for applications encompassing smart grid, microgrid, fault isolation and limiting, and pulsed power to name a few. This is because achieving fast switchable and controllable power flow at very high voltages and power  s difficult to achieve using present silicon based technology. The SiC HV optical ETO can fill that gap on ematured. Finally, the project led to the guidance of students and researchers, publications in quality journals and conferences, and invited presentations.
